Evaluation_Questions: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Comments_Questions: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
Comments_List: Learned basics and general overview of finance.
I learned quite a bit of new finance stuff.
Basic underpinnings of finance.
I learned a lot about options, capital budgeting, capital structuring, valuation of cashflows, etc.,  and I gained a lot of financial intuition.
I learned so much! Corporate accounting, financing decisions, bonds, forward rates, etc. basically how firms generate capital

Gained a solid foundation in corporate finance with respect to capital budgeting, bond and option pricing, discounting cash flows, understanding how the financial system works and how it is regulated, etc.
I learned so much about finance. Very informative course to teach beginners the basics of the math that goes into finance.
The course gave me a great understanding of corporate finance both on a practical and more theoretical level.
Theoretical and practical understanding of corporate finance, portfolio management, and other important aspects of finance and markets.

I learned a ton about corporate finance - things I'd never heard of before. Everything was so relevant to the real world and to the work world. I can see myself using this information to make business decisions in my future job. Most relevant class at Yale in terms of real life.
I learned quite a bit about aspects of finance ranging from corporate structure to complex valuation models.
I learned an enormous number of financial skills that I'm certain will be incredibly useful throughout my education and career.
Strong foundation in finance concepts, lots of applications in career
As someone who knew next to nothing about finance, this class gave me the basic framework for understanding the decisions made by businesses, banks, and investors on a day to day basis.
I learned a lot about corporate finance. This isn't quite an intro class so you shouldn't come into this class knowing nothing about finance but you will learn A TON.
I had no previous corporate finance knowledge and this course does a great job teaching the different areas.
Great overview of bond pricing, options, financial basics, and real-world applications.
Time value of money, dividends, corporate structure, derivative options, IPOs.
Solid Finance knowledge
Capital structure, capital budgeting decisions, time value of money, intro to options theory

Throughout the course of this class, I learned several fundamental concepts to corporate finance. Beginning with solid building blocks like accounting basics and ending with more conceptual ideas like corporate governance, this class really ran the gamut of what an introductory finance class was like. Going in, I had no idea what to expect of a finance class. However, this class has taught me the hard finance aspect of a corporation, the more soft conceptual ideas that go into financial decision making, as well as what it is like to truly work in finance (per Professor Pascutti). This really was a well-rounded class that did a great job in connecting class ideas to the real world.
Corporate Finance

I gained knowledge about both the practical applications of corporate finance as well as the academic and theoretical foundations of the subject. I learned the basics of accounting, corporate capital structures, raising funds, evaluating investment projects, the CAPM, and more.
Good financial foundation.
Nothing
It was a great introduction to finance but very difficult
General finance information. A lot of breadth over a ton of topics rather than depth. It doesn't assume any prior knowledge but the people who had background experience were much better off.
I learned so much in this course that I would never have learned otherwise. Great intro to bonds, valuation, and so much more
Corporate financial theories including accounting, bond pricing, valuation metrics, corporate structure, agency problems, option pricing, and portfolio management.
I learned basic finance terminology and concepts.
GREAT overview of all the basics of corporate finance (e.g., accounting, valuation, capital budgeting, etc.)
Big picture understanding of finance

Learned how a balance sheet interacts with an income statement and cash flows. Annuities, perpetuities, everything you need to know about bonds, stock pricing, net present value of projects, option pricing in European and American markets
A great intro finance course that covers options, stock pricing, cash flows, etc.
I learned a lot about what corporate finance actually means. I feel like this is one of the few really useful technical classes that Yale has to offer.
I gained a working knowledge of the math and the vocabulary of corporate finance.
A fundamental understanding of corporate finance. Relevant jargon, equations and applications. Learned how to analyze financial problems more critically.

The course provides an invaluable survey of the mathematical and conceptual tools necessary to value, manage and intelligently talk about corporations. Would recommend highly if you're thinking about entering strategic / management consulting or finance or even if you're just considering putting together a portfolio for yourself.

This course offers a great introduction to basic finance in the corporate world. I probably got more real-world applicable knowledge from this course than any others I have taken at Yale. You learn about the basics of US corporations and how to analyze there business decisions. I feel much more confident about going into the corporate world after college now that I have taken this.
Almost all areas of corporate finance are taught in this course, so you learn a lot.
Great introduction to corporate finance. This will give you a really good first look at what finance is all about.
I learned that Corporate Finance is all about practicing it.
Not just an introduction, but really the core of what corporate finance is and the key concepts of the field.

I learned a lot of the core finance. That means the intuition behind key financial formulas, strategies, etc. This is very much a theory class rather than a real world class, but it teaches you the core theory behind basic finance.

I learned skills that are useful in the financial and real world in general, such as bond, stock, and annuity valuations.  Professor Pascutti provided us with real world examples of different financial concepts as well.
Greater understanding of how corporations are organized and how their actions affect the stock market.
Great overview of all the basic parts of finance such as bonds, shares, dividends, options, etc.

The professor was pretty engaging and would bring in real world examples to showcase how topics we learn are actually seen in the real world. 

However, since we would be on a time crunch he would breeze by connecting what we learned to his real world examples making it almost pointless.

Strengths: gives a real sense of what finance is and its function in the real world.  Very useful for students to learn the basics of finances whether or not finance is an interest of yours. 
Weaknesses: I think there is too much material in the course.  I think it would be better if we learned less but learned it more thoroughly.  Additionally, the amount of math required in this course means it should be a QR credit - problem sets are all math.

Strengths:

interesting lectures
assignments

weaknesses:

tough curve because a lot of people already know finance stuff

Good overview of topics. I love that Pascutti doesn't use a PowerPoint in class -- it actually keeps you engaged in class. He's funny and clearly cares about the subject. Exams were difficult, long, and harshly graded, but it doesn't matter as the course is curved. Very little I would change about the course!
The strength of this course is that you end up learning a lot about finance. The weakness is that it's pretty difficult, and the average of the exams usually hovers at around 50%.
Professor Pascutti is so great. Clearly loves what he is doing and cares mostly that his students learn. I like how there was 2 midterms instead of 1

Strengths: engaging professor, comprehensive syllabus, well-structured subjects/themes.
Improvements: problem sets overall were helpful for understanding material and not unreasonable problems, but too many problems and took too long. Long exams that made it difficult to check over work or even finish.
Spending more time on applications and real-world examples of the theories discussed would help to ground the information we learn.

Strengths: The professor put a lot of effort into the course. Wanted and used feedback. Super relevant material - never felt like I was learning useless things.
Weaknesses: It was just so hard. So hard. I worked so hard in this course and was confused most of the time. The material is very challenging and there is so much of it. I remember remarking, while studying for the midterms, that there was more material to cover than I had ever had to cover for a midterm. This course could definitely be spread over a year. The professor spoke very quickly and went through material at lightening speed. Also, we never knew what our grades would be. Still don't know. It was really hard to tell how I was doing in the course. He refused to give concrete information on the grading curve and scale.

The main strength of this course is that it spends the first month laying a strong quantitative foundation such that students who previously might not have had the math background required would not be left behind.

The course was fantastic. After covering each topic, we explored ways in which information or skills could be applied to the real-world, whether thinking through potential scenarios or analyzing large corporations.
Strengths include the professor, lots of accessible course content and resources, helpful sections, and more. Weaknesses are the general organization and progression of content.
I believe the only weakness is how many people sign up for this class. I think it would be better with fewer people.

The problem sets for this class are confusing and a take a long time but you do learn the material (if you do them on your own). Sometimes the class seems all over the place. Also Pascutti can test you on things he said once in class so you have to pay attention.
The course was very interesting but it could have done better in organization.
An amazing course that teaches you a good overview of financial theory. Would require some background in finance (not much)because he skips over some basics fairly quickly.

There is a disconnect between what is taught in lecture and the PSETs. The weekly TA-led sections actually taught us what we were supposed to know for the PSETs. 

Criticism: 
*Essentially, Pascutti is not the most organized teacher. 

1. The answer keys to each of the seven PSETs had at least 2-5 typos on them. Sometimes the answer keys were not step-by-step either, making it hard to follow the solutions. Thus, as a student taking an INTRODUCTORY course on corp. fin., it makes you question whether the work you did was correct or if the answer key was wrong. 

2. The class syllabus specifically stated: "2 Midterm Exams: (40%) Closed book but you will be allowed to bring one page of notes or equations." Several classes before the first midterm, Pascutti told us that we wouldn't be allowed to bring out own notes to the midterm, and instead, he'd provide us with his own equation sheets. Obviously he did not abide by what the syllabus said -- but of course no one in the class would bother to address it and just deal with it. 

3. The syllabus listed the topics that would be learned on that class day. However, Pascutti rarely covered all of the topics that were to be learned that day. It was confusing to keep track of what you learned in lecture vs. what was supposed to be learned (according to the syllabus). Also, the syllabus told us which chapters in the textbook to read -- however, if on Tuesday we were supposed to read all of Chapter 15, but Pascutti only covered 15.1-15.3, were we responsible for reading the rest of Chp 15. for the midterms? Students should not have to figure this out themselves -- Pascutti should have been A LOT more explicitly organized. If he didn't cover something in lecture, then he should've made a Canvas announcement to tell us, "The syllabus said we were supposed to learn X today, but we didn't, so you are NOT responsible for knowing it for the PSETs/midterms" or "The syllabus said we were supposed to learn Y today, and we didn't get to it, so next class I'll address it."

3.5. My recommendation would be to just follow the textbook more. Incorporate more figures / problems from the chapters into your lecture. Actually GO OVER relevant, example problems in lecture. Maybe include some of the conceptual questions from the back of the textbook in the PSETs.     

4. Don't ask stupid (read: not the most relevant) questions on the midterm if you aren't going to ask stupid questions on the PSETs. Don't make a stupid question like "What are the top ratings for Moody's and the S&P", which can be answered in 5-6 letters, worth 12-15 points, while at the same time making a time-consuming NPV calculation question worth 10-15 points. It doesn't make sense... 


Positive Things: 
*However, Pascutti /does/ care about his students and he was willing to meet with them one-on-one. Additionally, he asked for weekly feedback and replied to what students had to tell him throughout the semester, which no professor really does at Yale. He is a good teacher now and I am confident he will be a better teacher in the future.
Good overview of many topics essential to the world of finance.

Good contents, Prof. Pascutti has clear explanations

Course materials are sometimes disorganized

Problem sets do a very good job of solidifying content. Lectures and lecture notes are not organized very well. Weekly feedback emails were helpful for looking at the bigger picture. Exams were fair but the final was very long and tedious.

This course was organized in a very logical procession, such that later concepts built on and utilized previous concepts very well. As a result, if I understood earlier concepts better, it made much more sense as I was approaching new problems. I also thought that the class times were utilized very efficiently; we certainly aimed to cover a lot of material in class, so there was never a wasted moment. Between the class lectures and the supplementary readings and problem sets, I thought the course did a good idea of emphasizing what portions were most important to grasp. As for areas of improvement, I understand that this might not have been possible considering how new the course is, but it would be awesome if future courses could maybe have peer tutors to help out with problem sets.
A lot of material

Professor Pascutti is a definite strength of the course. He brings an impressive knowledge to the classroom, and his perspective as a practitioner was especially interesting. Another strength of the course was the material it covered, which was both interesting and useful. One potential way to improve the course would be to tailor some of the topics to closely address the specific knowledge students would be expected to know going into entry-level finance roles or interviews - such as by seeking input from hiring managers, the Office of Career Strategy, or interviewers - as it seemed that many students were preparing for interviews and hoped the course would augment this preparation.

Strengths: broad intro into finance, covering the basics quickly but well

Weaknesses: lack of coherent lecture slides or practice material, section TAs were impossible to understand or follow, the exams were much harder than the problem sets.
Felt that the material wasn't tested fairly.
tfs were almost useless

You can learn a lot in the class but it is very fast paced. Also, the grading is quite arbitrary. The TAs grade the exams and assignments and the professor detached himself from that process so that he can't be held accountable but also won't fix it.
Strength is subject matter, weakness is the inconsistent grading by the TAs
Very high-level at times, requires you to prepare for class in order to fully understand class material, but overall very interesting.
The course felt disorganized. The lectures had no structure.

professor pascutti doesnt really do example problems in class, which is good because that means class time is used to learn concepts, however it makes the psets hard. Be prepared to use the book to figure out the psets (or find a TA that does example problems in section). Also lectures are very interesting, but can be a little disorganized at times.
Professor Pascutti is the kindest man, but the class would greatly benefit from slides or a more structured use of the textbook to help with review
Pascutti is awesome, no negatives

Great class, important material, but psets were often difficult if you had a bad TA, as most of that material was covered in section. TAs just need to communicate more with each other and standardize the material they teach and how they do it.

ECON 255 is a great course for undergraduates with an interest in business/finance. The lectures are interesting and informative, the exams are tough yet fair, and the course really prepares students with a baseline understanding of some of the fundamental concepts of the corporate world.

Pascutti is a phenomenal professor and covers everything in just enough detail to draw you in without getting too complicated. The one issue I have was that there was a clear disconnect between the professor and his TFs when it came to grading standards for the midterms, and without the professor actually grading, it was hard to tell what answers were creditable.
A strength was that the material was very interesting and engaging. A weakness was that there didnt feel like there was much structure.

I enjoyed how real world-applicable the concepts we learned  were. I see myself using a majority of the concepts in my job someday.

One weakness of the course would be the lack of feedback on test grades. They were harshly graded... Partial credit would be nice and more representative of the knowledge the student actually knows (a small calculation error shouldn't screw you over).

The lectures are great, Prof Pascutti is a great lecturer and if you're interested in the content you'll enjoy it. However, the psets are oftentimes not really related to lecture so that can be a struggle.
The course grading could be more clear. We also needed more communication between the TF's and the teacher for clarity.

The course is structured well, covering a true variety of content. Does not follow a textbook or any formal materials, but just what Professor Pascutti deems important. Would be great to have more finance courses in the department to be able to go more in-depth in some of the things Professor Pascutti could only spare one lecture for.
Strengths of engaged teacher and wide range of financial topics relevant to everyday life; weaknesses of occasional deep and narrow aspects to lectures and mundane (think pset handholding) sections

Pascutti is a great lecturer and very nice, which is the best thing about the class. The only issue is the class is slightly less organized than some, and a lot of the PSet/exam problems do not line up directly with lecture. That makes the class pretty hard. The average on both midterms was around a 50%.

I really enjoyed all the material we covered in class, and thought it was very interesting.  One thing that I thought could be improved is the weekly structure - the material kind of jumped around day by day and didn't really follow a specific schedule.
Also, either a textbook to follow along with or no textbook at all would be helpful.
The material can be very dry at times and the professor does well at livening up the material. Also, the textbook is very little help and determining what will be on the exams can be difficult.

The class is very well organized and the material is interesting, however, the pace could be balanced out because the first half of the course requires much more work than the second half. In addition, more reference to the textbook would be handy and going over the pset material would be helpful too.
Yes. Pascutti was engaging, the material was practical and applicable--best econ course I've taken.
I would. Take it with people that you know so you could work on problem sets together
If you have a basic interest in finance, take it, but be prepared to be challenged and you will have to work hard to get a good grade.  That being said, you will learn a lot taking this class.

Looks nice on a resume, but is tough to get a good grade in if you don't have a lot of time to study or you don't already know a lot about finance. I ended up taking it credit/d. Paschutti is a pretty interesting and engaging lecturer.
Yes! Important material and great instructor.

I would absolutely not recommend this course to another student at Yale. Pascutti is easily one of the worst, if not the worst, professor I have had. 

There was not a single problem set solution in which he did not have a typo, which made me distrust the rest of this answers. He also writes all of the solutions in word, without using equation formatting. This might seem like a small detail but when you are going through a million problems to study for an exam and this is how everything is formatted: 5/(1+0.3)*(1+1/(1+0.02)^140) it gets annoying. We get it, you don't come from academia, but please just get a TA that knows how to use Latec and can also proofread your typos. 

Pascutti does not make powerpoints for class, he just scribbles on the board and goes through a list of topics. However, he is so disorganized that it is extremely difficult to follow which concepts he is talking about.  In addition, he does a terrible job introducing new concepts. If you don't have background knowledge, this class will be very difficult to understand.

Piazza is available for the course, but Pascutti changed it so the names were not anonymous to him halfway through the semester, and he began to be really mean in his answers. Here are some examples of his answers: "Everything we talked about in class,"  "I have already tried to be clear about this," "I don't know how you could have interpreted this differently." I really don't understand the point of having piazza if you are going berate people for asking questions.

I took this class because because I thought it would help with interviews, I ended up wishing I read book on this and instead used this credit for more a interesting course at Yale. Don't be fooled by Pascutti's energetic personality during shopping period. I'll leave you with that.
Yes, I'd recommend this course because the material is useful to know in life. However, the psets are hard and so are the exams.
Take this course if you have any interest in learning about corporate financing decisions. It is not easy, but worth it in my opinion. You will learn a lot
Yes if you have any interest in finance (not only as a career but from a conceptual viewpoint)
Yes. I learned a lot and the professor is very clear and accessible
If you want to learn more about business and finance, definitely take it. The material is not too easy, but it's definitely manageable. Prof. Pascutti puts a lot of time and is very approachable.

The course is quite difficult. I would recommend taking it CRD/D. An enormous amount of material is covered in a short period of time. Pascutti is a good teacher and you can gain a lot from this course.

Yes, I highly recommend, but with the caveat that it will be extremely difficult. You will be stressed. It's super useful if you want to work in finance or even just business. Definitely good for an ECON credit, too. But I would like to see what the future of this course looks like; this is one of the first years he has taught it, so he's still figuring out what works best. Depending on what grade I get, too, would change my recommendation!

I would absolutely recommend this course to a friend on the condition that they are actually interested in finance. The class requires quite a bit of work and is going to prove difficult if you aren't interested.
Absolutely! This course is fantastic for anyone who is interested in the material and is up for a bit of a challenge. Strongly recommend!

Yes, this is a fantastic class in corporate finance that will give you a thorough understanding of the financial ends of all types of businesses. I have no intention of going into finance, and I still thought this was a fantastic course.
Great foundation for finance stuff
I would 100% recommend this course to another student. These are important concepts that very few people truly understand.

I recommend this class to people genuinely interested in finance. The tests are hard, the problem sets are hard, so don't waste your time if you're just trying to get an Econ elective. Pascutti is incredibly engaging and interesting, but he is very smart and does not have time for students that are not fully engaged with the class.
Yes, I would recommend the course if there were new TF's involved. I think Pascutti does a great job lecturing but the in depth teaching was lacking.
Would highly recommend to anyone going into finance (S&T or banking) because the course provides a great overview of mathematical applications and Pascutti is freaking hilarious.

I would not recommend this class, but the stuff you learn in it is interesting and relevant for life, so I would recommend you learn this at some point in your life. As a non-econ major, I decided to take this course to become financially literate. I will first talk about the bad things and then the good things about this class. 

Criticism: 
*Essentially, Pascutti is not the most organized teacher. 

1. The answer keys to each of the seven PSETs had at least 2-5 typos on them. Sometimes the answer keys were not step-by-step either, making it hard to follow the solutions. Thus, as a student taking an INTRODUCTORY course on corp. fin., it makes you question whether the work you did was correct or if the answer key was wrong. 

2. The class syllabus specifically stated: "2 Midterm Exams: (40%) Closed book but you will be allowed to bring one page of notes or equations." Several classes before the first midterm, Pascutti told us that we wouldn't be allowed to bring out own notes to the midterm, and instead, he'd provide us with his own equation sheets. Obviously he did not abide by what the syllabus said -- but of course no one in the class would bother to address it and just deal with it. 

3. The syllabus listed the topics that would be learned on that class day. However, Pascutti rarely covered all of the topics that were to be learned that day. It was confusing to keep track of what you learned in lecture vs. what was supposed to be learned (according to the syllabus). Also, the syllabus told us which chapters in the textbook to read -- however, if on Tuesday we were supposed to read all of Chapter 15, but Pascutti only covered 15.1-15.3, were we responsible for reading the rest of Chp 15. for the midterms? Students should not have to figure this out themselves -- Pascutti should have been A LOT more explicitly organized. If he didn't cover something in lecture, then he should've made a Canvas announcement to tell us, "The syllabus said we were supposed to learn X today, but we didn't, so you are NOT responsible for knowing it for the PSETs/midterms" or "The syllabus said we were supposed to learn Y today, and we didn't get to it, so next class I'll address it."

3.5. My recommendation would be to just follow the textbook more. Incorporate more figures / problems from the chapters into your lecture. Actually GO OVER relevant, example problems in lecture. Maybe include some of the conceptual questions from the back of the textbook in the PSETs.     

4. Don't ask stupid (read: not the most relevant) questions on the midterm if you aren't going to ask stupid questions on the PSETs. Don't make a stupid question like "What are the top ratings for Moody's and the S&P", which can be answered in 5-6 letters, worth 12-15 points, while at the same time making a time-consuming NPV calculation question worth 10-15 points. It doesn't make sense... 


Positive Things: 
*However, Pascutti /does/ care about his students and he was willing to meet with them one-on-one. Additionally, he asked for weekly feedback and replied to what students had to tell him throughout the semester, which no professor really does at Yale. He is a good teacher now and I am confident he will be a better teacher in the future.
Yes. Great course to learn about finance.
Will recommend if you want to know about finance!

Yes, this class is a great introduction to a lot of different topics in corporate finance. But be warned that classes are not organized very well, so lectures might feel somewhat confusing the first time around. Put in the time to complete the PSETs and understand what is going on, it will pay dividends later in the course.

I would recommend this course to anyone who is interested in finance or just wants to learn a little more about it. Regardless of whether or not you are thinking of a career in finance, I think this class did a great job in teaching you fundamental concepts that are important for life in general. The learning curve was a bit steep for someone like myself, who had gone in without any finance knowledge whatsoever, but I felt that if you immerse yourself and really take the time to learn the material, you will come out knowing a lot more than you did prior.
Avoid if pascutti
Yes if you are an econ major

I would recommend this course to another student, especially one with a basic background in finance who is interested in gaining more knowledge and a more comprehensive view of the subject. The course covers a wide range of topics, challenging students while teaching them foundational knowledge that can be applied in a finance role or in academic research.
No, unless youre some kind of masochistic finance nerd
My least favorite class taken at Yale, I would highly recommend not taking it. It doesn't help with getting a job, which is seemingly why most people take it, and the material is pretty useless.
only if you have prior knowledge
Probably not unless you are taking it credit/d or have done a summer in finance, otherwise it's really too much stress.
Yes! If you have an interest in this subject, Pascutti is the best teacher for it and this is the only class at gale that really caters to finance
Great course. If youre interested in finance definitely take it
Yes, but prepare to be challenged (as any good class should do)!
Yes, if the student wants to be familiar with finance.

Yes! Great overview of all the important finance topics. If youre planning to do finance/ consulting/ etc this class is a must. And even if youre just going to work at a company, I still think this would be helpful to give you a basic understanding of how finance works and explains why companies make the decisions they do.
Yes but credit D!!!

I completely recommendend this class. Pascutti is an amazing professor and you learn a lot. The Psets are actually helpful in facilitating learning and getting prepared for exams. One of the best classes Ive taken at Yale thus far, 10/10 would take again
Great course just be prepared for almost weekly psets, two midterms, and a final!
I would recommend im this to anyone who is at all interested in corporate finance. It is definitely a useful class. Try to take with Professor Pascutti if possible.
Yes, it is the one of the most engaging Econ classes to take at Yale, thanks to Pascutti.

ECON 255 is a great course for undergraduates with an interest in business/finance. The lectures are interesting and informative, the exams are tough yet fair, and the course really prepares students with a baseline understanding of some of the fundamental concepts of the corporate world.

Absolutely. If you'd like to develop a fundamental grasp on the field of corporate finance this class is for you. The learning curve can be steep at times, but that's the nature of the material. Take it as a credit/d if you'd like; the material and professor are phenomenal but the grading can be inconsistent.

If you are planning on going into the corporate world, this course is a great introduction to what you'll be dealing with. You begin to think about money and financial decisions in a different way-considering risk and the cost of time.
Yes, interesting material and a very good instructor.
This is a great Credit D if you're interested in finance. You'll learn a lot and have great lectures.
I would because I enjoyed the material... but the class grading and tests were unclear.

Definitely not an easy course, but if you are interested in corporate finance, absolutely. Many kids go into it thinking they can take it for job or interview prep, but this is very misguided. This course is not designed for and will not be able to help you land your internship, but will enable you to read and understand every financial term you thought you knew but really didn't.

This is a good basic finance course. Pascutti made it clear his goal is to have the course designated a core Econ course, and it shows. A lot of the material is very relevant to what comes up in the newspapers and just useful to know for everyday life in general, and Pascutti's teaching is solid, traveling to offer office hours and giving more or less weekly feedback via email, nice for a lecture. I'm not an aspiring consultant/banker/trader but still found most of the material interesting; some topics like options trading and different asset pricing models were a bit narrower than I would have preferred but seem necessary for other applications, more or less, so take that how you will.

The class is what you sign up for and put into it. Pascutti has a ton of knowledge and can be a great teacher. He will teach you a lot (I knew none of the material ahead of time). However, it will be a hard class, so keep in mind that you will have to read the book sometimes and study hard. The averages on midterms is low, so I'm hoping for a good curve.
A true gem as an introduction to finance.
If you are interested in corporate structure and the stock market, this class can be interesting at times.
Would totally recommend if you're even just slightly interested in finance.
I would recommend this course if you're interested at all in finance, even if you have no idea of what finance entails.
